ThesisContext.title: The Longitudinal Effects of Social Media Use on Adolescent Well-Being: A Multi-Country Panel Study
research_questions: What is the causal relationship between daily social media use and adolescent well-being over a 3-year period?
Do effects differ by platform type (visual vs. text-based) and usage pattern (passive vs. active)?
How do socioeconomic and cultural factors moderate the relationship between social media use and well-being?
contributions: Largest longitudinal dataset linking adolescent social media use to well-being outcomes (N=45,000 across 12 countries)
Novel distinction between active and passive use with differential effects
Cross-cultural analysis revealing significant variation in effect sizes by cultural context
Pre-registered analysis plan with extensive robustness checks

terminology_glossary.definition: A composite measure including life satisfaction, positive affect, and absence of depressive symptoms
Research design involving repeated observations of the same variables over time
A longitudinal study that surveys the same individuals at multiple time points
Social media consumption without active engagement (scrolling, viewing content)
Social media engagement involving content creation or direct interaction
A quantitative measure of the magnitude of a phenomenon
